= Software Development Story=
I literally learned my software engineering job from the internet. 
Out of work construction worker when the market crashed in 2007.
I was blessed to be able to just find something I found interesting, and just 
dug in. I had always thought home automation was cool, so I started playing 
with Linux. Linux led me to learning scripts. Scripts led me to wanting 
more of a 'system'. Wanting that 'system' for home automation led me to an 
open source project, LinuxMCE. LinuxMCE had lots of code I was able to slowly 
take piece by piece, understand, and improve. All at my own speed. Started 
with basic patches to the media management that let you add metadata to 
video files. Just some php and html with some JSON sprinkled in there. 
And learning to work with databases. Then, with that under my belt I 
approached c++. From there i learned how to write an interface for the 
Phillips hue system in c++ so that everyone could use it with LinuxMCE.
Fast forward 5 years, ive written multiple c++ components, and ported the 
application to android. At this point, I started shopping my resume around 
with a link to my work and was able to get hired as a Qt Software engineer.
I should point out, im a HEAVY Qt user as it make the multi-platform life for 
most of the applications I develop easier. But i've had to write native java 
applications as well, so its not all Qt all the time. Stick with it! It can 
be frustrating, but hang in there! I have a great software engineering job 
now and my resume was essentially my OSS development work. Plus, working in 
the OSS field allows you to develop a thick skin and people skills. Or not ;)

-Focus on one thing, and do it really really well

{{{

void main()
{
int A[]={4,14,24,34};
int B[]={6,16,26,36};
int C[]={9,19,29,39};

int *ptr[3];
int **pptr;
int i;

ptr[0]=A;
ptr[1]=B;
ptr[2]=C;

pptr=ptr;

for(i=1;i<=3;i++)
{
*pptr+=i;
**pptr+=i;
++pptr;
}
--pptr;
printf("\n%d", **pptr);
for(i=0;i<3;i++)
printf("%d", *ptr[i]);

for(i=0;i<4;i++)
printf("\n %d %d %d",A[i],B[i],C[i]);
}

}}}

{

}


printf("\nPosition\tLength\t\tString\n\n");

{

}
}

}
